articles.headline: How Kamala Harris Forged Close Ties With Big Tech
articles.snippet: Silicon Valley has enthusiastically backed Ms. Harris since she first ran for state attorney general in California a decade ago.
articles.abstract: Silicon Valley has enthusiastically backed Ms. Harris since she first ran for state attorney general in California a decade ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Kamala Harris, then San Francisco’s district attorney, was running to become California’s attorney general in 2010, she did not hide her excitement about speaking at Google’s Silicon Valley campus.
articles.byline: By Daisuke Wakabayashi, Stephanie Saul and Kenneth P. Vogel

articles.headline: Pledging to Tell More Inclusive Stories, MGM Remakes Orion Pictures
articles.snippet: The 36-year-old producer Alana Mayo will lead the division, which will release two or three films a year and focus exclusively on underrepresented filmmakers.
articles.abstract: The 36-year-old producer Alana Mayo will lead the division, which will release two or three films a year and focus exclusively on underrepresented filmmakers.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Checks have been written to racial justice organizations. Training programs for Asian, Black and Latino filmmakers have been created. “We must do better” has been tweeted and retweeted by studio executives, most recently after the killing of George Floyd in police custody prompted a national conversation about racism and inequity.

articles.headline: Former Uber Security Chief Charged With Concealing Hack
articles.snippet: Joe Sullivan, who led Uber’s security team through the company’s most tumultuous period, was fired by the company’s newly installed chief executive in 2017.
articles.abstract: Joe Sullivan, who led Uber’s security team through the company’s most tumultuous period, was fired by the company’s newly installed chief executive in 2017.
articles.lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Uber’s former security chief was charged on Thursday with attempting to conceal from federal investigators a hack that exposed the email addresses and phone numbers of 57 million drivers and passengers.

articles.headline: The Republican Embrace of QAnon Goes Far Beyond Trump
articles.snippet: As the president all but endorses the internet-driven conspiracy theory, it is shifting from the fringes of the internet to become an offline political movement.
articles.abstract: As the president all but endorses the internet-driven conspiracy theory, it is shifting from the fringes of the internet to become an offline political movement.
articles.lead_paragraph: Late last month, as the Texas Republican Party was shifting into campaign mode, it unveiled a new slogan, lifting a rallying cry straight from a once-unthinkable source: the internet-driven conspiracy theory known as QAnon.
articles.byline: By Matthew Rosenberg and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Joe Biden Finally Got the Timing Right
articles.snippet: More than three decades after his first presidential run, in the midst of a deadly pandemic and without his son Beau at his side, the former vice president has met his moment.
articles.abstract: More than three decades after his first presidential run, in the midst of a deadly pandemic and without his son Beau at his side, the former vice president has met his moment.
articles.lead_paragraph: Joe Biden tells funny stories at funerals and sad ones at campaign stops.

articles.headline: Biden Leaves Convention With a Clear Mission: Stop Trump
articles.snippet: Mr. Biden rides out of the D.N.C. with a general election message centered on compassion, linking his biography of setback and recovery to the lives of Americans experiencing hardships.
articles.abstract: Mr. Biden rides out of the D.N.C. with a general election message centered on compassion, linking his biography of setback and recovery to the lives of Americans experiencing hardships.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the newly minted leader of the Democratic Party, Joseph R. Biden Jr. used his acceptance speech on Thursday night to lay out an unusually personal message for the fall campaign, linking his heart-rending biography of setback and recovery to the lives of Americans hoping for their own rebound in a season of hardships.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Shane Goldmacher

articles.headline: Unemployment Claims Rise as Rollout of $300 Benefit Lags
articles.snippet: With the labor market showing new fragility, most states have yet to seek funds under President Trump’s stopgap plan to supplement weekly jobless pay.
articles.abstract: With the labor market showing new fragility, most states have yet to seek funds under President Trump’s stopgap plan to supplement weekly jobless pay.
articles.lead_paragraph: The job market shows signs of softening, even as a move by President Trump to replace lost unemployment benefits is struggling to get off the ground.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Tiffany Hsu

articles.headline: Joe Biden Accepts Democratic Nomination: ‘I Will Draw on the Best of Us’
articles.snippet: Mr. Biden urged Americans to have faith that they could “overcome this season of darkness,” and he pledged to bridge the country’s divisions in ways President Trump had not.
articles.abstract: Mr. Biden urged Americans to have faith that they could “overcome this season of darkness,” and he pledged to bridge the country’s divisions in ways President Trump had not.
articles.lead_paragraph: Joseph R. Biden Jr. accepted the Democratic presidential nomination on Thursday night, beginning a general-election challenge to President Trump that Democrats cast this week as a rescue mission for a country equally besieged by a crippling pandemic and a White House defined by incompetence, racism and abuse of power.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns and Katie Glueck

articles.headline: The Chick’s in the Mail? Rural America Faces New Worries With Postal Crisis
articles.snippet: The Postal Service is crucial to farmers and rural areas that President Trump won in 2016. Now, residents worry it is being dismantled.
articles.abstract: The Postal Service is crucial to farmers and rural areas that President Trump won in 2016. Now, residents worry it is being dismantled.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rhiannon Hampson thought she would hear a cacophony of cheeping when she went to her post office in coastal Maine to fetch a delivery of newly hatched chicks. But the cardboard boxes addressed to her poultry farm were silent.

articles.headline: Goldman Sachs Has Money. It Has Power. And Now It Has a Font
articles.snippet: The custom-made Goldman Sans is ‘neutral, with a wink’ — or boring and derivative, according to fontheads.
articles.abstract: The custom-made Goldman Sans is ‘neutral, with a wink’ — or boring and derivative, according to fontheads.
articles.lead_paragraph: There are so few ways to express yourself when you’re Goldman Sachs. Sure, you can commission a 10-part documentary series about your company’s history, and your chief executive can moonlight as a D.J. in the Hamptons. But how do you let the masses know what it’s like to really be you, the bank, in your everyday functions, processing financial spreadsheets and taking companies public?
articles.byline: By Josh Wagner and Joel Stein

articles.headline: We Have Crossed the Line Debt Hawks Warned Us About for Decades
articles.snippet: The debt of the United States now exceeds the size of its gross domestic product. That was considered a doomsday scenario that would wreck the economy. So far, that hasn’t happened.
articles.abstract: The debt of the United States now exceeds the size of its gross domestic product. That was considered a doomsday scenario that would wreck the economy. So far, that hasn’t happened.
articles.lead_paragraph: Economists and deficit hawks have warned for decades that the United States was borrowing too much money. The federal debt was ballooning so fast, they said, that economic ruin was inevitable: Interest rates would skyrocket, taxes would rise and inflation would probably run wild.

articles.headline: Xi Declares War on Food Waste, and China Races to Tighten Its Belt
articles.snippet: The Communist Party’s “clean plate” campaign targets livestreaming extreme eaters, wasteful diners and others amid concerns about China’s ability to feed its 1.4 billion people.
articles.abstract: The Communist Party’s “clean plate” campaign targets livestreaming extreme eaters, wasteful diners and others amid concerns about China’s ability to feed its 1.4 billion people.
articles.lead_paragraph: Chinese regulators are calling out livestreamers who binge-eat for promoting excessive consumption. A school said it would bar students from applying for scholarships if their daily leftovers exceeded a set amount. A restaurant placed electronic scales at its entrance for customers to weigh themselves to avoid ordering too much.
articles.byline: By Bella Huang and Amy Qin

articles.headline: They’re Making the Rent. Is It Costing Their Future?
articles.snippet: Federal aid and eviction bans have kept many tenants in their homes. With that support ebbing, it can take charity and sacrifice to avoid dislocation.
articles.abstract: Federal aid and eviction bans have kept many tenants in their homes. With that support ebbing, it can take charity and sacrifice to avoid dislocation.
articles.lead_paragraph: They’ve made it with government checks and family help. They’ve made it with savings and odd jobs. They’ve made it with church charity, nonprofit rescue funds, GoFundMe campaigns. One way or another, through five months of economic dislocation, the nation’s tenants have for the most part made their rent.
articles.byline: By Conor Dougherty and Gillian Friedman

articles.headline: Facebook Braces Itself for Trump to Cast Doubt on Election Results
articles.snippet: The world’s biggest social network is working out what steps to take should President Trump use its platform to dispute the vote.
articles.abstract: The world’s biggest social network is working out what steps to take should President Trump use its platform to dispute the vote.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook spent years preparing to ward off any tampering on its site ahead of November’s presidential election. Now the social network is getting ready in case President Trump interferes once the vote is over.
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac and Sheera Frenkel
